description:
Arenibacter nanhaiticus is a species of bacteria that was isolated from sediment collected from the South China Sea. It is a Gram-negative, aerobic, and non-spore-forming bacterium. Cells of A. nanhaiticus are rod-shaped and motile, with a single polar flagellum. The optimal growth temperature for this species is around 30Â°C, and it can grow in the presence of up to 7% (w/v) NaCl, indicating its adaptation to saline environments.

Phylogenetically, A. nanhaiticus belongs to the genus Arenibacter, which is classified within the family Flavobacteriaceae of the phylum Bacteroidetes. Comparative analysis of the 16S rRNA gene sequence has shown that A. nanhaiticus is most closely related to other Arenibacter species, such as A. latericius and A. palladensis, sharing around 95-96% sequence similarity.

This bacterium has been found to produce various hydrolytic enzymes, including amylase, lipase, and protease, suggesting its potential role in the degradation of organic matter in marine sediments. Further studies on the ecology, physiology, and potential applications of A. nanhaiticus may provide insights into its function and significance in the marine environment.
